Here's a simple trick for you that I picked up as a kid:

Pick a number from 1 to 100 (don't tell me)
multiply by 3
add 9
divide by 3
subtract the number you picked
Your answer is 3.

...


Why does this work?
Write up the process as an algebra equation, with x being the number you picked.
((x*3+9)/3)-x
reduces to
x+3-x
reduces to
3.

I figured out a super cool method for finding square roots from (the first two terms of) the taylor series:

Sqrt(x) ~ (x/a+a)/2 where a is a guess for the root

Sqrt(32) is between 5 and 6 so let's guess 5.5
(32/5.5+5.5)/2 = 5.659
Sqrt(32) = 5.657

This is a convergent series so you can put the new approximation back in to get an even better guess. It's a great way to tack on lots of decimal places of accuracy using only long division. To do a second iteration, we could guess 5.66 (rounding to do less dividing) and get 5.656855 where the real answer is 5.656854! Even just trying 5.7 gives 5.65701 which is only off by 0.00016

Dividing can be a pain but it beats guess and check!

I figured out a fun way to multiply by 8s on your fingers. Using one hand, you count, via the fingers, the number you want to multiply 8 by, then double the number of fingers+thumb to the right of the lowered finger. For example, 8x2 would look like [I-IIi]. This shows [10+(3x2)]=16 Doubling the fingers+thumb on the right gives a result of 16.

(I = an up finger, - = a down finger, i = a thumb, and [ ] are used to distinguish between the two hands.)

For multiplying past 6, cycle the down finger back around to the start and use the fingers on your other hand as placeholders, each equal to 40.

So, 8x9 would end up showing the following: [III-i][i----], which is [30+(1x2)]+[40]=72.
And, 8x22 would end with: [I-IIi][iIII-], which is [10+(3x2)]+[40+40+40+40]=176.

I'm happy bc I just came up with this on my own! Plus, it allows you to multiply by 8s up to 30.

If you add up the digits of any integer and the result is a multiple of nine then the original number is divisible by nine no matter what the order of the digits.  ie. 27, 2+7=9, 27/9=3.  270/7=30, 720/9=80.  It also works for three.  If an integer's digits add up to a multiple of three then the number is divisible by three.  ie. 3125814 added up is 24 which is divisible by three 3125814/3=1041938.  Again, it doesn't matter what order the digits are in, it will still be divisible by three.  Try randomizing the digits 3125814 and any combination will evenly divide by three.  cool! 3:08, that’s a trivial pattern. For a base B, you’re saying that (B-1)*(B-2) = (B-3)*B + 2.

Clearly, the left side is equal to B^2 -3B + 2, and if we factor out the B from the first two terms we get B(B-3) + 2.

Unrelated, your first line isn’t very good: it says “base 10”, which has literally no meaning, since by definition “10” is the base in whatever base you’re using. I’d use “A” or “X” instead.

The tip on tipping can be thought of or said differently.  Rather than thjnking "move the decimal place left one place" think "divide by 10" .  Where Z is the total.cost, a 20% tip is Z divided by 10 times 2.   [ ($170/10 = $17) X 2 ] = $34].  Moving the decimal point left 1 space is dividing by 10.  To me "dividing by 10" is a quicker and easier way to think of it.  But, neither is wrong.  And if you simplify the equation, a 20% tip really is just Z divided by 5, which is even easier on some totals.  A total of $55.  The 20% tip is $11.  I usually round the dollar value to the nearest number ending in 0 or 5 and divide by 5, which gives either a >19%, 20%, or <21% tip.  I figure close enough.  So, $173 = Roundedup$175/5 = $35 tip, a little over 20%.  $172 = roundedDown$170/5 = $34 tip.  A little lower than 20%.  How much lower?  An exact 20% tip on $173 is $173/5 = $34.60.  The rounded down tip is $34.  So the rounded down tip is 60 cents less than an exact 20% tip.  But its still more than a 19% tip.  An exact 19% tip on $173 = $32.87.  So the rounded down tip of $34 is $34 - $32.87= $1.13 greater than a 19% tip.  So the rounded down tip is $0.60 less than 20% tip and $1.13 greater than 19% tip.  I figure close enough, and also my karma probably averages out between the round-up tips and round-down tips over time.  😁. Wow!  Now that was a very satisfying nerdification exercise on my part.  Sorry.  Your channel covers physics and math.  A nerd magnet.

For me, the easiest way to calculate a 20% tip is to take 10% of whatever the bill is and then double it. So, using your example, if my bill was $170, I'd take 10% of it, which would equal 17 and then double that number to get 34. That's the tip: $34 and it's super quick and easy to do.

That said... you really don't even need to calculate a tip nowadays because the waiter or waitress brings over a portable card scanner, so after you've slid your credit card in and entered your PIN, the scanner then asks if you want to leave a tip and gives you the option of using a percentage or a specific number. If you choose the percentage option, you'll get several choices (usually ranging from 10% to 30%) and the machine does the calculation for you.

At least that's how it's done in Canada. I've noticed in the past that Americans seem to get confused when confronted with the whole chip-and-PIN setup.

A simpler way to find (not precisely) a square root of number:
If we have √55 we can find the closest to 55 which its root is a whole number and smaller than 55 which it's 49 and √49 is 7.
Now, we subtract 49 from 55 and get 6 (55-49=6) and lastly multiply 55 by 2 and get 110.
With those results we can say that √55 equals 7 and 6/110 (776/110). It's not precise but close.

sqrt(32) = sqrt(2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2)

Count how many pairs are under the radical and pull them out as singles:

2 * 2 * sqrt(2) = 4sqrt(2)

If you don’t know the approximate value of sqrt(2) is 1.41... , you can still tell

1 < sqrt(2) < 2

And get a good idea (you probably aren’t going for accuracy anyway if you aren’t pulling out your phone), otherwise

sqrt(32) ~= 5.64

My physics professor told me that I apparently do arithmetic and algebra in my head way faster than she can, so a lot of this was pretty simple to me right off the bat.

Like you said 20% of $10 is $2. That's a great method to use because even when you had a $170 bill you can just think to yourself "Huh, $170 is just 17 $10s, so 17×$2 is $34". The moving the decimal place back on that problem is the equivalent of realizing how many tens there are in the number and just multiplying by the 20%.

Also, when you do 9×n, instead of using your fingers (I don't actually know if that's what you do), at least what I do is that I find what the closest multiple of 9 is for n that I remember, then I do that multiple and subtract off (or add) however many multiples was needed to get the correct answer. For example, 9×13: well, 9×10 is 90 and 9×3 is 27, so 90+27=117. Another would be 12×32: 12×10=120, and there are 3 10s in 30, so 120×3=360 (12×3=36, so add a 0 whenever there's a 0 on one side), and then we are left with a multiple of 2 leftover from the 30 which means that 360×2=720 (or 36×2=(30×2)+(6×2)=60+12=72, then add that pesky 0).

Arithmetic is actually pretty easy to do in one's head after a while, and becomes rather quick to perform given enough practice during times when you have to invent something to do to keep from being bored.

To get a square of any number ending with 5, isolate the five, multiply what's left with one number higher than itself, then write 25 to the far right.

Examples:

65^2= 4225
(6*7) = 42 (then write 25)

115^2=13225
(11*12)=132 (then write 25)

275^2= 75625
(27*28)= 756 (then add 25)

You never explained how you got to 715, 364, and 924 in the chinese remainder theorem trick! It was bothering me and I remembered a little bit of group theory and linear algebra, so I think I have a working explanation, but I don't remember many of the theorems that support it.

I started by noticing that 715 % (modulo) 7 = 1, 715 % 11 = 0, and 715 % 13 = 0 as well. This looked interesting to me because when I originally saw the number 1001 and that its prime factorization was 7, 11, and 13, I wondered if the trick was based on a result in math that allows you to create a vector space or group/ring where each number from 1 to 1001 could be assigned a unique coordinate based on the remainder when divided by each of the prime factors. Thus, 715 looks a bit like a "basis" vector for the 7 "coordinate". I then checked 364, which appeared to be a basis vector for the 11 "coordinate" where 364 % 7 = 0, 364 % 11 = 1, and 364 % 13 = 0. Lastly, the same pattern held for 924 with 13.

I then realized that by multiplying each of the remainders by this basis vector we would get a number where it's remainder when divided by the other two coordinates would still be 0, but the remainder when dividing by the basis vector "coordinate" would match the remainder of the hidden mystery number that we're trying to figure out. For example, 3 x 364 = 1092. 1092 % 7 = 0, 1092 % 11 = 3, 1092 % 13 = 0.

Finally, when adding two numbers we know that the sum % n will be the sum of each number we are adding % n, so adding all of the numbers up at the end gives us a number where such that it's modulo of all the prime factors we started with is equal to the mystery number, and because this pattern repeats every 1001 numbers, we can take our sum % 1001 to get the original number with the correct remainder "coodinates".

If I am correct, this could be expanded at minimum to include any number who's prime factorization has no powers of primes greater than 1. I still don't know if this would work for prime factorizations with powers of primes greater than 1, but my suspicion is that it would still work, except with the divisors being each of the primes to it's highest power.

Here's another trick. Take any odd number, square it and divide by two. The original odd number and the two nearest integers to the division result form a Pythagorean triplet.  E.g.: 3, squared is 9, divide by two to get 4.5. Two closest integers are 4 & 5, so triplet is 3,4,5. Easy to prove: (x+1)^2 = x^2 + (2x + 1)  When 2x + 1 is a perfect square you have the triplet.

In some of these tricks, there is multiplication/division by powers of 10. It sounds less imposing to call this, "shifting."
That is, you keep the decimal point (dp) fixed, and shift all the digits right or left some number of places.
Or keep the digits fixed and move the dp that many places in the opposite direction.
To multiply by 10, shift left 1 place/or move the point right 1.
To multiply by 100, shift left 2 places/move the point right 2.
To divide by 10, shift right 1 place/move the point left 1.

1. Taking 20%; i.e., multiplying by 0.2; i.e., dividing by 5:
Move the dp left 1 and double.
BTW, you can do the same, but in reverse, to multiply by 5

2. Multiplying by 11:
The trick she gives for two-digit numbers is fine, but what about longer numbers? Do this:
Shift the number left 1 place, and add (to the original number). Of course, this just amounts to the usual method of muliplication. But you can adapt it to mental math by adding consecutive pairs of digits – the complication is applying all the carries. But if you're lucky and there are none, you can multiply by 11 lickety-split!
11 x 21536:
(0)+2=2
2+1=3
1+5=6
5+3=8
3+6=9
6+(0)=6
ANS: 236896

3. Multiplying by 9:
Once again, to extend this to more-than-2-digit numbers, do this:
Shift the number left 1 place (don't forget to slap a trailing "0" onto it!), and subtract the original number.
Her discovery at 3:08, works also in larger bases. You can verify it by treating the muliplication as being on polynomials, where the base you're in ("b"), is the variable:
(base b) (b–1)(b–2) = b² – 3b + 2 = (b–3)b + 2
. . so the base-b digits of the product are b–3 and 2

4. The square root trick, using geometry.
Unfortunately, even confined to just the (positive) integers, this trick will work only when the number can be written as a sum of two squares, n = x² + y², so that you can use x and y as the legs of your right triangle.

Fortunately, though, there are quite a few 2-square numbers. Aside from the squares, up through 50:
2, 5, 8, 10, 13, 17, 18, 20, 26, 29, 32, 34, 37, 40, 41, 45, 50
.. which are subject to the Pythagorean Theorem trick.
The non-2-square numbers are:
3, 6, 7, 11, 12, 14, 15, 19, 21, 22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 30, 31, 33, 35, 38, 39, 42, 43, 44, 46, 47, 48
.. and square roots of these can't be found by that method, as shown. An extension of it, however, will work for any (positive) integer.
[Hint: Every positive integer can be expressed as a sum of 4 or fewer squares.]

5. Chinese Remainder Theorem.
Pretty neat! Look it up for more info. It applies to any finite number of co-prime integers; it gets more complicated the more of them there are.


ADDENDUM:
4. When the number you want the √ of, isn't a sum of two squares (or even when it is!), you can always write it as a difference of two squares (even though sometimes those will have to be squares of half-integers), using the difference-of-squares factorization:
x² – y² = (x – y)(x + y)
For instance, 7 can't be written as a sum of fewer than 4 squares:
7 = 2² + 1² + 1² + 1²
but every odd integer is a difference of consecutive squares:
2n + 1 = (n+1)² – n² ; with n=3:
7 = 4² – 3²

So measure c = 4 units from one end of your pipe cleaner;
bend it there and measure b = 3 units;
bend it there into a 90º angle. The 3rd segment will be a when we're done.
Now, maintaining the 90º angle between b & a, flex the angles between c and b until the 3rd segment closes the triangle (meets the beginning end of the pipe cleaner.) a now = √7.

For n = 6, its minimum sum of squares is
6 = 2² + 1² + 1²

But n = 6 = 2·3 = (x – y)(x + y), x = ½(3+2) = ⁵/₂ , y = ½(3–2) = ½
6 = (⁵/₂)² – (½)²

So do what you did in the previous example, but now with
c = 2½
b = ½
You will get
a = √6

I never did that finger thing with the 9s. I was actually taught an easier method, imo.

Take any 9 times table under 1-10. Let's say 9 * 4.

Take the 4, subtract 1. You get 3.
Now subtract 3 from 9. You get 6.
Answer is 36.

Or, if you're more inclined, you can use your fingers (or count in your head if you prefer)
4 - 1 = 3. Then count the numbers from 3 to 9, you get 6. 36.

You can do this for any 9 times table, not just the ones 1-10. But it gets over complicated. The catch is that every time you enter a new set of 10, you have to multiply the trick one more time. So, for 1-10, you just subtract 1 and use 9. For 11-20, you subtract 2 and use 18 (9 * 2). For 21-30, you subtract 3 and use 27 (9 * 3), etc.

Say 9 * 18.

Take 18, subtract 2. You get 16.
Take 9 * 2 (18), then subtract 16. You get 2.
16 and 2: 162.

Or lets say 9 * 22.
Take 22, subtract 3. You get 19.
Take 9 * 3 (27), then subtract 19. You get 8.
19 and 8: 198.

Or lets say 9 * 35.
Take 35, subtract 4. You get 31.
Take 9 * 4 (36), then subtract 31. You get 5.
31 and 5: 315.

Or, take 9 * 40.
Take 40, subtract 5. You get 35.
Take 9 * 5 (45), then subtract 35. You get 10.
35 and 10: 360

The multiplying elevens trick reminded me! In the 7th grade, I came up with a trick for multiplying large numbers made of just 1's together. 12-year-old me was particularly proud of it. For example, quickly solving 11111 x 1111. The answer always starts at 1, ascends until a certain point, repeats that top number, then descends back to 1.

Examples:
111 x 11 = 1221
11111 x 1111 = 12344321
11111111 x 11111 = 123455554321
111111111 x 111111111 = 12345678987654321

And here's the trick:

The length (number of digits) of the smaller number is what you ascend to. Then take 1 plus the length of the larger number, minus the length of the smaller number, and that's how many times you repeat it.

So for example above: 11111 x 1111

Length of smaller number (1111) = 4 <-- What we ascend to
Length of larger number (11111) = 5
(5 + 1) - 4 = 2 <-- The number of times we repeat "4"

Result = 12344321

For larger numbers, you have to carry or just express the answer in a higher base ;)

Regarding the square root trick, there is a similar trick where you can calculate the complex result from raising any complex number to real power.
Lets take
(2+5i)^3.5 as an example, but this will work with any number. (so long as it's not raised to a complex power

Construct your right triangle with a length of 2 units and a height of 5 units.
now you may want to tape it down. you are going to imagine a coordinate system where the verticy made by the hypotenuse and the length is point (0,0)
define it so your length is parallel to the x axis, and the height is parallel to the y axis. (technically its the real and imaginary axis, but it doesnt matter)

Now, using a protractor measure the angle of the point at your origin (0,0)
multiply this angle by your power in this case multiply by 3.5, then using this new angle draw a line going out from there.

now measure the length of your hypotenuse. You need to take that length and raise it to 3.5
You can do this by taking its square root using the methods shown in this video, then raise its square root to the 7th power.
Now your almost done. starting from the origin, Draw a line with that angle you calculated earlier, to have a side length equal to the result of raising the hypotenuse to 3.5

Now all you need to do is from the end point of the line you drew find its coordinate.
Measure how much below or above the horizontal origin it is. you should fine, its roughly 310 units bellow.
Then measure how far left or right it is from the vertical origine line. And you should find it roughly 188 units to the left.
You now have your answer.
(-188-310i)

Squaring a number that ends in a 5 is pretty easy, too.
15^2 = 100*(1*2) + 25 = 225
25^2 = 100(2*3) + 25 = 625
55^2 = 100(5*6) + 25 = 3025

It works on decimals, too.
1.5^2 = (1*2) + 0.25 = 2.25
2.5^2 = (2*3) + 0.25 = 6.25

Expand as you like.
Happy squaring!

Square root (quick n dirty): take the nearest square and add (or subtract) the difference divided by twice the root of that nearest square.

For example 32 (7 more than 25 or 5x5 but 4 less than 36 or 6x6) so use '6' - 4/(2x6) or 6 - 1/3 = 5.667 - which is surpisingly close to the real answer [no pipe cleaner supply needed]
Example 47 (nearest square 49 or 7x7, difference of -2) gives 7 - 2/(2x7) = 7 - 1/7 = 6.857 (compare 6.85565...)

So this works really well.

Here's how I learned the 9's table: Subtract 1 from the number you're multiplying by, which gives you the first digit. Your second digit is the number you have to add to your first digit to get 9.

9 x 7:
7 - 1 = 6 <--- First digit
9 - 6 = 3 <--- Second digit
9 x 7 = 63

9 x 5:
5 - 1 = 4 <--- First digit
9 - 4 = 5 <--- Second digit
9 x 5 = 45
These are tricks for middle schoolers...

when I estimate square roots in my head.. I like to do linear approximation (calculus).. so for example.. if i want to find square root of 32.. i ask.. what's the closest perfect square? 36.. then i know root 36 is 6.. so root 32 must be LESS than 6.. so i must subtract something from this.. and it turns out (using calculus) that you need to subtract the derivative of the square root of x.. but since 32 is 4 away from that perfect square (36).. i need to multiple the derivative part by 4.. i'll just show what i'm talking about..

root(36) - 4 / [2*root(36)]
6 - 4 / [2*6]
6 - 4/12
6 - 1/3
5 and 2/3 or.. 5.666

and it turns out the answer is 5.6568.. which is pretty close.. and there's other tricks to make a better approximation.. but yeah.. woo! :D oh i met you in NYC and asked about physics textbooks.. i've been so busy.. i need to email you.. ahhh... but i need to go ok bye!
